What to eat after dental surgery

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎07-05-2010 08:33 PM

It has been a long, LONG time since I've been on these boards and have a question that I hope someone will be able to answer.

I'm in the middle of a huge dental undertaking and in a couple of weeks will be having all of my top teeth removed and will be left with six of my bottom teeth. I will immediately have an upper denture and partial plate on the bottom jaw.

Besides being scared to death, I have not been able to come up with foods that will not spike my blood sugar which are what are recommended to eat (ice cream, milk shakes, etc.). I've heard that i should keep to a liquid diet for a few days and then start adding in soft foods as my mouth heals.

I'll be able to make some softer foods prior to my surgery and have them ready to go when I'm up to it, but really am at a loss as to what to "drink" for the first few days that has a lot of protein and not a lot of carbs. I was kind of thinking baby (or Junior) food as it is pretty much pulverized and I could get meats and veggies in my system until I can start chewing things like scrambled eggs and other protein-laden items.

Any ideas?
Report Inappropriate Content

‎07-05-2010 09:00 PM

You might look at sugar free whey protein powder. It can be made into drinks. Dr Atkins shakes might work too. I think they are expensive and don't taste very good. They might work for this circumstance though.
Prediabetic
A1C
03/14 5,4
09/13 4.7
03/13 4.8
08/12 5.0

What to eat after dental surgery

Options

‎07-05-2010 09:16 PM

Hi Sharon, first of all welcome back! I missed you.

When Nancy (Powerwalker) had wisdom teeth out we had a long thread on the old board. I hope she reads this and jumps in. She had some great ideas.

I do remember that I had suggested a toddlers "sippy cup" and she did use one but took the valve out of it. The reason for that is that they prefer you not to do any real sucking. Something about needing the blot clots to remain in the empty socket in order to speed healing.

I recall that Nancy also used baby foods as well as her blender at the beginning.

The insertion of dentures immediately after surgery still shocks me, but I know it is common practice.

Even when you start on solids, I would recommend using a plastic spoon for most foods. It will avoid jarring of your mouth if you do happen to hit your new teeth.

Lots more are going to come along and I'll jump back in if I can recall some of the previous long and funny discussion.

Try and relax about this and keep in mind that you will end up with a wonderful smile. And way less flossing

Dianne
Dianne

Diagnosed as type 2 in 2005 with an A1c of 9.1

Started with metformin and a low dose of an ARB for blood pressure. Added a sulfonylurea (a med that helps my pancreas produce my own insulin) Also a low dose of Crestor to lower my cholesterol.
After 7 years I could no longer tolerate metformin so am doing my best to keep control with a max dose of the sulfonylurea and lots of walking, some swimming.

‎07-05-2010 10:01 PM

After my TMJ surgery, I wasn't allowed to chew anything for 3 months. I put everthing my family had in the food processor, including Christmas dinner. Didn't look so great, but I didn't starve or feel deprived
Barb T2 Omni Pod since 1-09

‎07-05-2010 10:02 PM


Thanks, Goldensun for your ideas!!

Dianne!!!! Thanks for the welcome back!! It has been ages and I missed you, as well!!

I�m glad to hear that Nancy ate baby food and other pureed foods when she went through her wisdom teeth removal. I hadn�t thought of a sippy cup, but it makes a lot of sense. I know that I have to be aware of not dislodging the blood clots and have a nice Starbucks travel mug that only allows a small amount of liquid to come out at one time, which I had planned on using. I will definitely add a sippy cup to my shopping list!! Great idea!!

The plastic utensils are also a fantastic idea that I hadn�t thought of. It makes perfect sense and I will certainly use them!

I�m looking forward to any information that others can bring to the table as well. I�m looking forward to my shiny new smile but getting there is another story. My dentist came highly recommended and I just love him and his staff. They have me on Valium �therapy� and are not stingy on keeping me comfortable if you know what I mean!

Tomorrow I have to have a tooth crowned and am not looking forward to that. In about 3 weeks, the �big� work will be done. Luckily I work for myself (and my husband, of course!) so I have already planned on not leaving the house for at least a week afterwards. I�ll need to start the healing process and also start learning how to talk again. I am not looking forward to any of this.

I�ve still not smoked a cigarette!! It has been two years and 1 month!! That will help the healing process as well.

You are so sweet to answer my post, Dianne!! I look forward to chatting with you again soon!! My email is Sharon@thejunkcarcompany.com and if you want to see my latest �hobby�, visit my photos at www.sharonsimmons.smugmug.com or www.flickr.com/photos/sugarsharon.

Thank you again!!

‎07-05-2010 11:58 PM

I recently was in a similar situation and discovered Jell-O sugar-free puddings. I also had quite a bit of soup, as well as plain Greek yogurt (Fage/Oikos/etc.) mixed with some fruit that I added myself (small bits that I could just swallow, rather than chew).
